scenes.location: PRINCESS OF WALES HOSPITAL, EMERGENCY ROOM
characters: A STACK OF RENTED PA SPEAKERS
OVER THE HOOD AND LANDS ON THE PAVEMENT A DOZEN YARDS
THE ACTUAL FACE OF QUEEN ELIZABETH II
A CHECK FOR THREE THOUSAND POUNDS
HIS SOLD-OUT TOURS HAVE CIRCLED THE GLOBE FIVE TIMES
IN 2008, HE HAD THE THIRD SURGERY OF HIS LIFE
PAUL IS THROWN FROM HIS BIKE, BOUNCES OFF THE WINDSHIELD,
A PHOTO OF THE REAL PAUL AND JULIE-ANN POTTS
AND SMASHES INTO HIM HEAD ON--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors fly open as a team of EMS WORKERS wheels in a YOUNG PAUL POTTS (9) lying on a gurney. His parents ROLAN and YVONNE POTTS follow. DR. THORPE (29) a new intern meets the team along with a NURSE...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE EMS
dialogues.text: Male, nine years old, possible ruptured eardrum.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: His name’s Paul.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Right. Room three, please. He follows the gurney into a triage room, while the nurse waylays Roland and Yvonne with her clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You’re his parents?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’‘1l just need to get some basic information from you.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (to his anxious wife) He'll be alright.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (filling in a form) Right, so it’s Paul...last name please?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Potts. P, O, double-T, S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Potts. Like the Cambodian dictator who massacred all the--?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (for the millionth time...) Not at all like the Cambodian dictator.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Right. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY (FLASHBACK) Shots of the choir... Four rows deep... First and third rows leading the song; rows two and four following severa bars behind... All eyes on the peripatetic CHOIRMASTER... Several rows behind the fourth row, Paul stands alone, singing with gale-force might...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PAUL
dialogues.text: O tidings of comfort and joy, comfort and joy. O tidings of comfort and joy. Several members of the fourth row wince at the decibel level as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gurney is locked into position as the medical team takes over. Yvonne wrings her hands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: How long since it occurred?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: About an bour. They said he just collapsed after his solo.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Miracle he hasn’t ruptured our eardrums from all his hooting and hollering.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (elbowing her husband) He’s a passionate singer. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY (FLASHBACK) Where Paul sways as he solos with eyes fervently shut, hands clenched, voice like a wind throughout the cathedral...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear not then said the angel, let nothing you affright. This day is born a Savoir of a pure Virgin bright. To free all those who trust in Him--

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR
dialogues.text: --from Satan's power and might. O tidings of comfort and joy. A distinct THUMP is heard... The members of the fourth ro look over their shoulders to find Paul is vanished from sight.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Comfort and joy. O tidings of comfort and Jjoy-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul is wheeled into surgery. Young Dr. Thorpe, now in gown and gloves, meets his parents at the door...

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: --got some fluid build-up in the middle ear. Not to worry, we'll have him right as rain in no time.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: So you've done this sort of thing before?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Of course. Well, not with anyone still breathing... (realizes the faux pas) I’m still new, but rest assured, live or dead, the bits are all the same once you start digging around inside. (now they’re freaked) Cafe’s just down the hall. He heads into surgery... As the doors swing shut--

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (arm around his wife) He'll be just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-story row house adjoined on either side and identical to the sixty other homes on the block.  The door slams behind Paul, who stands on the landing, carrying his school bag. He pats the large bandage mummifying his repaired ear, then looks both ways before descending the steps to the sidewalk. He checks his surroundings again before venturing out the gate and turning down the road.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: There he is! Get ‘im! Paul runs as a flock of screaming YOUNG BOYS crosses the road, hot on his heels... Their screams blend into the continuing choral medley as we return to... INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY Where the same Welsh choir-faces, several years older now continue the song with undiminished fervor over--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shots of this gray, industrial steel-town huddled on the edge of the Celtic Sea. From above the city, we see Paul, a lone figure running down the center of a road...a moment later the group of boys appears in close pursuit until they catch him and start punching... INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY Reveal that the rows behind the choir are empty... And yet, Paul’s voice rises above the rest, though it sounds impossibly far away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul tears around a corner, the lead pursuers close behin him... He’s slightly older now, closer to thirteen or fourteen with a few extra pounds... He cuts across a busy intersection, narrowly avoiding a lorry which momentarily cuts off his pursuers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul weaves through pedestrians. He’s aged again, nearing eighteen, and puffing even harder with the extra weight. The boys chasing him appear older, larger, and there are more of them than before and they’re gaining on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul turns down the empty alley, losing his schoolbag to the clutching hand of the closest pursuer... Near the alley’s end, Paul veers wide to the left in anticipation, then cuts right, barely fitting his belly through a narrow pedestrian opening... The lead boys miss the turn, smacking into the alley wall and crumple... INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY Paul’s hidden voice is somewhat louder now as the CAMERA looks down on the choir from above...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks back to see his lead has widened. He smiles then turns forward an instant too late to avoid the newly constructed scaffolding on the sidewalk... He opens his mouth to scream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul lies on the ground, mouth bleeding, bullies standing over him, laughing. MATTHEW, the toughest of the lot, leans forward and allows a stream of spit to dribble onto Paul’s cheek where it mixes with the blood from his ruined mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul is brought in on another gurney where he’s met by a slightly aged Dr. Thorpe.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: What’ve we got?

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR
dialogues.text: Among your friends and kindred that live both far and near. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY CAMERA PULLS OUT of the shattered mouth of PAUL, now in his twenties, singing, with reckless fervor through the shards of two badly broken front teeth...  CAMERA CONTINUES pulling back to reveal he is alone, in the upper choir loft, a good twenty feet above the rest o the choir.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That god send you a happy new year, happy new year. That god send you a happy new year. INT. ST. CATHERINE’S CHURCH - DAY The Choirmaster’s fists clench shut, silencing the choir.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: That’s very nice indeed. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walls lined with various phones and phone accessories. BRADDON (34), painfully thin with spiky hair, bad skin an elvish ear-extensions, hits on a FEMALE CUSTOMER.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Now this one comes with customizable ringtones and dual vibrating mode, which can come in quite handy in certain situations. The bell jingles as Paul walks in quietly.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: And what situations would that be?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (leaning closer) What’ve you got in mind?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: I'd like a word with your manager. He shows her his employee badge, that reads “MANAGER” jus below his name, “BRADDON MELLINS”.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: They should lock you up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Bondage? Naughty, cheeky, but presto, you talked me into it.  She storms out...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come see us again soon. ---passing Paul who offers a tentative, closed-mouth smil to Braddon. Hands him

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Better luck next time.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It’s quantum algebra, mate; if I offer my personal services to twenty women, one point three of them are certain to shag me blind.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How many have said yes so far?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (calculating) S’about... I’m still tinkering with the approach, but erection is the mother of invention, yes? Right, what can we do ya for? Something compact, ‘round five- hundred minutes a month with unlimited text and a free shaving kit?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Actually, I was wondering if the position’s still open.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: The position?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The job.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: You want to work here, what in god’s name for?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Because I love mobile phones?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Lying will get you everywhere. an application, then snatches it back...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you got a girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Well, sort of-- Not really. Braddon snatches the application back again...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Boyfriend then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh no, she’s definitely a girl, I’m sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Okay, as long as you’re sure. Paul takes the application and gets to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul walks home from the interview, passes a pub, The Forge Tavern, from which numerous UNION MEN have spilled out onto the sidewalk. Paul lowers his head and gives the men a wide berth, unti one DRUNK man stumbles into him and “accidentally” drops his beer.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRUNK
dialogues.text: Watch where you’re going, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry. He tries not to break stride, but the man grabs his arm threateningly...

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRUNK
dialogues.text: Sorry ain’t gonna pay for a new pint, is it? Suddenly, the drunk is jerked backwards and ends up on hi ass.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (standing over him) I’‘1l thank you to leave him alone now, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRUNK
dialogues.text: ‘Not my fault he can’t walk straight.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DRUNK
dialogues.text: Probably ‘cause his teeth are all crooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or it’s that enormous ass of his.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: One more word.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DRUNK
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: And your next shift will be in the queue at the unemployment office. Finally, they all back down to his seniority. Roland help the First Drunk to his feet--

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now come on Bill and apologize to-- But Paul is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul walks down the center of the road. Roland jogs after him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: All right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m fine, dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Pete’s a good lad, he’s just in his cups is all. Paul doesn’t respond. They walk for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe if you joined a fitness club. Lifted some weights.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I’m just saying... Maybe losin’ a few stone you wouldn’t provoke them as much. Paul looks away; not the first time he’s heard this brand of logic from his father.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I got a job.  10.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What, that bloody musical down the community centre?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mobile phone shop in Bridgend.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oh... Well done... So, you’ll be getting your own place then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Actually, um, I’ve been saving up for opera lessons...in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You’re twenty-nine years old, Paul. Singing lessons can wait. They turn up the path to their home. Paul hesitates a moment letting Roland go up the steps ahead of him. Furious, he opens his mouth to speak, but loses his nerve... Music is heard - Pavarotti singing “Che Gelida Manina” from La Boeme.

dialogues.speaker: PAGLIACCT
dialogues.text: INT. PAUL’S BEDROOM - NIGHT TRACK ACROSS walls plastered with posters and downloaded print-outs of images from the opera world: The Three Tenors; Caruso; a program from La Traviata in Rome; and finally a virtual shrine to Pavarotti, his great hero...

dialogues.speaker: A PAIR OF KNITTING NEEDLES
dialogues.text: Pointed skyward, quivering slightly in anticipation... Then slicing and waving through the air as Paul angrily “conducts” the music as the refrain kicks in. Gradually, Paul is enveloped and the thrashing needles slow and subside and finally slip to the ground as, panting, he stops the record, revealing a muffled BANGING coming from downstairs.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul makes his way down the stairs and into the kitche where Roland is already at the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Always with the bloody violins. Won't shed a tear when they’ve packed and gone.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (serving dinner) What do you mean gone? Paul, are you going somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Venice.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oh no, this singing rubbish has gone on long enough. He’s got a job, he can get his own flat.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Pish-posh. (to Paul) Stay forever darling. Here you are. As she places an enormous plate in front of Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Christ, Yvonne, He can hardly fit through the door as it is.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (to Roland) Look, I get it. I’m never going to be a professional singer. I just... It’s the only thing that makes me-- Let me go to Venice and I'll move out when I get back. Yvonne looks at Roland, eyes pleading Paul’s case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul, gasping and sweating and carrying two moving boxes, climbs several flights up the increasingly narrow staircase until he reaches the top floor and the door to-  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he drops the boxes alongside several others. The room is partially unpacked with his pictures of Pavarotti and Toscanini already hung with prominence, and his computer has been set up atop a “desk” made from several other boxes. A CHIMING/BOUNCING MESSAGE is seen on the screen... Paul clicks on the message revealing a kitty-kat avatar, which expands into a Chat Invitation from “julzRulz”.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (typed) How did it go? Paul TYPES his response...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How did what go?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Job? Italy? Job? Italy?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Job, yes. Smallest apartment in Britain, yes. Italy, no. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Paul. I guess you'll have to settle for visiting me in Bristol. Hint. Hint. ;) :) A beat as Paul flushes... He types...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd love to, but the job starts tomorrow and until I get the cast off my leg, it’s too difficult for me to get around. Paul grimaces at the lie.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (after a beat...) Right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If I ask you something, promise not to get offended?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Anything?  13.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You are a girl-- (deletes the word girl, replaces it with...) --a woman, right? He sighs with relief at her response and continues “chatting.”

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I could feel the firming of her breasts as she pressed them into me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Braddon is in mid-soliloquy as he and Paul stock shelves with bluetooth ear-pieces...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: “Be gentle,” said she. “Unicorns are not meant for human love.” “But lady,” said I, “I am only half human.” And I laid her down and took her there, amidst the moss and leaves of the forest floor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And that was your weekend?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: In a nutshell. Yours?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry, but... Did you say you shagged a horse?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It’s a game, role-playing, like Dungeons & Dragons but for real.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So she was a girl, pretending to be a horse.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: A unicorn!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right... Sorry. And you were--?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: A half-elf wizard from the Black Mages Guild of Quilanthum.  14.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: When’s the last time you had a bit of fluff?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Em, well...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She is a girl, by the way. My girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: When shall we double-date then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Um, she doesn’t really live here.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Where’s she live, then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bristol.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Bristol? That’s miles from-- You have actually met her, haven’t you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, we chat all the time... Shows Braddon his phone-chat which shows a lengthy text- thread between he and julzRulz.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She keeps inviting me up for a visit, but...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, she looks like Cameron Diaz and...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: And? Suddenly Paul sees something over Braddon’s shoulder and darts through the curtains into the back of the store.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s crawled up his-- He turns to the storefront where Matthew enters belligerently, wearing a blue janitor’s uniform and carrying a smashed cell phone...

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: The service on this phone is total crap!

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It can’t be bad as all that. I can see quarter crap, or maybe even half-- As Matthew dumps the smashed cell phone on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right, the thing is, in order for the service to actually work, the phone itself should really be in no more than three or four pieces.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: (threatening) It’s under warranty.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Of course, but--

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: How ‘bout you gimme a phone that works properly and I won’t cram this one down your throat. Yeh? Braddon glances at the cel phone Paul left on the counter then at the curtains at the back of the store.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Braddon lock up for the night.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Oh, nearly forgot. Flips Paul his phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Thanks.  16.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: I took the liberty, while you were cowering in the back...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I wasn’t cowering, I was-- Took the liberty to do what?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: This Saturday, Swansea Railway Station. She’s on the nine fifteen train. Walks off leaving Paul dumbfounded...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul catches up with Braddon.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It's a bit difficult losing your virginity someone a hundred miles away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You invited her here?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: You did. As far as she knows. And what’s this rubbish about a broken leg?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I told her that so-- She said she looks like Cameron Diaz!

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: How awful.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It is!

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: In what universe could that be-- (realizing...) You told her you look like someone famous as well?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A bit, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Robbie Coltraine? Jack Black? Madonna?  17.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Worse.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Worse than Madonna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taped to a mirror-frame in which Paul is seen not coming within a million miles of emulating Pitt’s hair-style. Finally, he gives up and tears the photo from the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul waits nervously as the train arrives. He practices several nonchalant leans against a pole before giving up entirely. PASSENGERS flood from the train as the doors open. Paul searches through them, looking for a Cameron Diaz clone. The train pulls away and the crowd thins until Paul is alone on the platform. His heart sinks a little - she stood him up.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Brad? He turns around and has to hide his smile...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Cameron? JULIE-ANNE “JULZ” COOPER, cute but short and thoroughly relieved that she’s not the only one who exaggerated her appearance, smiles back at him. They smile at each other for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um, welcome to Port Talbot.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (laughing at him, but ina good way) Thank you. They turn and walk towards the far end of the platform, each taking turns stealing glances at one another.  18. At one point, their hands touch and Paul’s fingers close around hers... The continue walking, neither speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still holding hands, Paul and Julz walk amidst shoppers.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You’re leg’s much better.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (touching his left leg) Yeah, thanks. Ship-shape. (off her look) What?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I thought it was your right leg?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Um...

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paul, is that you darling?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh god. Yvonne appears through the crowd, carrying bags of food from Sainsbury’s and an incredulous look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Well, bless my soul. Hallo, I’m Paul’s mum. Paul dies a little inside as Julz has to wrest her hand from his to shake Yvonne’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Lovely to meet you. I’m Julz.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Paul, you didn’t tell me you were... Oh you must come for dinner. My husband would love to--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks, mum, but Julz has to be back to the station by--  19.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (seeing Yvonne's disappointment ) It's alright. I'd love to come. Can we help you with these? She takes several of Yvonne’s bags.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Thank you dear. Aren’t you lovely? Julz looks at Paul. Mouths the word, “Okay?” Paul can’t help but nod and smile/grimace. Julz sticks her tongue ou at him before Yvonne pulls her onwards...

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now then, tell me everything about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the four of them are packed around the small table loaded with food.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: --but then I thought to myself, I haven’t got the slightest interest in die-cast aluminum figurines. So I got a job in the pharmacy at Boots.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Good retirement benefits at Boots.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Not so good as Car Phone Warehouse. (to Yvonne) That’s lovely, thanks. Yvonne has piled a towering stack of green-beans on Julz’ plate.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: And your parents? What do they do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: It’s alright. Mum’s a--  20.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Her mum’s a seamstress and Dad’s on disability from the chemical plant.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Smithsons the one in Bristol?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That’s right. And I hear you’re the foreman down the steel mill? And you, Yvonne, are said to make the best bread pudding in all of Europe.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: I am somewhat celebrated for it.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (nudging Paul) Not the only celebrity in the family.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What? Him?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He’s going to be a wonderful singer.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I thought you two only met this morning? Julz takes Paul’s hand under the table.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Nonsense. How could I be his girlfriend if we'd only just met? Paul brightens at this news, as does Yvonne.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: They've been chirping on the Internet for quite some time, dear.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s not chirping, mum, it’s--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: We've been chirping for almost a year.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: With all the chirping and singing, it’s no wonder he’s so undeveloped. Paul’s eyes fall to his lap...  21.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You think Paul is undeveloped?!

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I wish my mum did all my washing when I was twenty-nine.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL YVONNE
dialogues.text: I can’t stop her. You just try and stop me! Everyone’s taken aback by Yvonne’s ferocity...

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Now then, who’s for a sweet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yvonne kisses Julz several times goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: I mean it. Even if Paul’s not here, we can go for a ladies lunch or have our hair done.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Sounds wonderful. Roland appears, palms a packet of condoms into Paul’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Can’t be too careful. Paul pockets them quickly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bye then. Forces his parents inside and pulls the door closed on them. Yvonne is heard yelling at Roland.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Condoms?! Are you out of your bloody mind?!

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (to Paul) He didn’t?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who knows what her intentions are!  22.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (flushed, shows her the condoms ) I’m sorry. I--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What kind of a tart does he think I am?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (to Roland) She’s a lovely girl.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My point exactly. What’s a girl like that want with the likes of him, then?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) She’s after his inheritance! All twenty pounds of it. Hurry, we must hide the Picassos. Julz watches Paul’s face, feeling badly for him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dad fell on his head when he was a child. Or last week perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (re: the condoms) Well, you won’t be needing those, just so’s you don’t have any ideas.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don’t! I swear. The thought hasn’t even crossed my-- (he’s gone too far) I mean. It has, but... I mean... She puts her finger to her lips. Offers her hand. He take it and they walk off. EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - DAY Paul and Julz sit outside over pints of cider.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He was just mean, really. Shagged my former best friend, then told me it’s because I was getting too-- (eyes reddening) It doesn’t matter.  23.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) He was a tosser.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: An enormous tosser. But I’m well past it... I don’t need that much love, I don’t expect it anyway, not coming from where I do. But, nothing ventured, nothing gained as they say... You’ve got to take chances now and again, though it'd be brilliant if it was on something actually worthwhile for change. Paul smiles... He wants to tell her he’s worthwhile, but knows it isn’t something you say... Instead, he traces outlines with his thumb across the back of her hand until

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If you could be one person, who would you be?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Well, seeing as I’m a dead ringer for Cameron Diaz... (flutters her eyelashes) Then again, she’s got her own career, famous boyfriends, and an ass I'd sell my mum for. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd be me.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: ‘Can't be yourself. Have to be someone else.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be someone else.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That confident, are we?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: On the contrary. But, if I were someone else, I wouldn’t be here with you.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You’ll get a kiss later for that one... Okay, what if you could meet anyone? Now that I’ve met Brad Pitt, I’1l have to say...Nelson Mandela.  24.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Pavarotti.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He’s your true role model then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It used to be him and Han Solo, but then I realized Han Solo wasn’t actually real.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Crushing was it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Horrible scars on my psyche.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He’s Italian? Pavarotti, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He lives in Monte Carlo now, but he’s on the board of an opera school in Venice.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That's where you want to go, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not good enough to sing professionally, I just like singing for people. It’d be nice to learn properly. Maybe someday.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Would you sing for me? Paul flushes red. Smiles shyly but is clearly uncomfortable...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s not that I--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Someday, then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Someday.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: One foot, then the other. Suddenly, the door bursts open and Braddon emerges along with HYDRANGEA, an ethereal looking girl with blonde hair and a unicorn shirt.  25.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: What do you mean platonic? How can you be- Hallo Paul. What you doing here? (sees Julz) Is this-- This is! You are!

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She is. (to Hydrangea) And you must be--

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: Hydrangea.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right. (re: her shirt) Is that a unicorn? Braddon signals desperately for him to shut up.

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: Have you signed up for the contest?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just the cider.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Just as well, I’ve got the blue ribbon in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What bag is that?

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: Third annual Halloween costume karaoke competition. Three thousand pound to the winner. Pulls a flyer off the wall, hands it to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (stunned) Three thousand pound?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Mind you, it’s no amateur night. They get some pretty tough customers in here. (bangs his bird chest) It’s sure be a blood-bath.  26.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You’re a singer, then are you?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (as if it’s obvious...) I’ve got a gorgeous singing voice. (kissing Julz hand) Lovely to meet you. (kisses Paul’s hand) And you. Tries to kiss Hydrangea’s hand, but she flicks him in the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: Come on, Sinatra. You can wash my motor- scooter.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It that code? (off her look) Oh. Right. She drags him away, leaving Julz looking at the embarrassed Paul with raised eyebrows...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Actually, he’s my boss.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You’re joking?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The less you think about him the better. INT. PAUL’S BEDROOM - DAY Only slightly progressed since last time. The boxes are gone and yet it feels even smaller. Julz marvels at the collection of opera posters and flyers.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Wow. I knew you were into opera, but I didn’t know you were completely mad for it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not fanatical about it or anything. (off her look) Okay, maybe just a little bit. Julz looks at a yellowed, framed newspaper article...  27.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What language is this?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Portuguese. It’s the--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You speak Portuguese?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not at all. I had it translated though. It's the story of Toscanini’s first performance in 1886... Realizes he’s probably boring her.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Go on. She glances at his knitting needles on the bedside tables... He’s relieved when she doesn’t ask...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He was a cellist in an Italian opera company that was touring South America. (points to the date) One night in 1886, their conductor was booed by the audience and literally forced to leave the podium. In desperation, the singers suggested their assistant Chorus Master take over because he knew the whole opera by heart.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That’s a lot to memorize, is it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Um, yes it is. And though he had never conducted anything before, Toscanini threw aside the score and led a sensational, two-and-a-half hour performance completely from memory. He was nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: And then he became quite famous, didn’t he? She’s seeing his deepest desires on his sleeve. He realizes he’s gotten carried away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry.  He smiles 28.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: For what? I wish I loved something that much.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There must be something?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Not yet, anyway. as he realizes she means him.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best get to my train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Julz stand side-by-side, still holding hands as her train pulls in, neither wanting the day to end.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I had a lovely day.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I had a lovely day. An awkward beat. Paul has no idea what to do as the train stops.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Sooo, I'll see you when you get back then.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: From where?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Venice, of course.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I told you, I’m not going to Italy.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You are. You're going to win that karaoke competition and if the next time we speak you’re not ringing me from a Venetian gondola, I mightn’t think you can sing at all. Then she kisses him, deeply, soundly, with just a bit of tongue.  29.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (gobsmacked) Right.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: See ya Brad.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bye Cameron. Almost without thought, he pulls her to him and kisses he again. Gradually realizing he might have been too forward as evidenced by the shy look on his face as their lips part... The smile that blooms in her mouth and eyes says otherwis as she opens one of the train doors and climbs aboard. He follows her down the train until she finds a seat. He waves and smiles and she closes her eyes and kisses the window between them. The glass steams from her breath and she draws a heart around the imprint of her lipstick. The train pulls away leaving Paul alone but brimming on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of BUS PASSENGERS staring at something in the back of the bus... Reveal Paul, dressed in a puffy, white clown costume with large neck ruffles, grapefruit-sized pom-poms, a fake beard and white face paint with black, vertical lines bisecting his eyes. He feels the stares and tries to look as if he doesn’t notice them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you gone completely up the pole? EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT Paul looks down at himself, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's Pavarotti... As Canio... It’s really that bad?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: You look like a dead marshmallow.  30.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh. So that’s-- What’s you’re costume, then?

dialogues.speaker: A STACK OF RENTED PA SPEAKERS
dialogues.text: INT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT The opening beats and squeaks of George Michael’s “I Want Your Sex” blare... Braddon jumps into frame, wearing nothing but a thin pizz box around his waist...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: There's things that you guess. And things that you know. There's boys you can trust. And girls that you don't. There's little things you hide. (indicates his groin) And things that you show. (turns, showing everyone his butt) Sometimes you think you're gonna get it. But you don't and that's just the way it goes. The audience is stunned, but some are laughing, and Hydrangea, dressed in shimmery white robes with a tiny nu of horn atop her forehead, sings along to the chorus as Braddon thrusts his pizza box at her.

dialogues.speaker: UNICORN GIRL
dialogues.text: I swear I won't tease you. Won't tell you no lies. I don't need no bible. Just look in my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT Braddon does an awkward split as the song ends.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: C-c-c-c-c-c-come on! The audience cheers and laughs as he climbs to his feet, trying to hold the pizza box together. Hydrangea hugs him and pulls him into the crowd next to Paul who’s still in shock.  31.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well done.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Yeah thanks, mate. It’s a gift from-- Kisses his finger then points to heaven... Over by the karaoke equipment, the EMCEE reads from his list.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: And now, singing... Blimey... (squints) Vesti la goober. The vocal stylings of Paul Poots. Braddon and Hydrangea clap wildly, shoving Paul onto the stage. The audience quiets for a moment, taking in his costume, until the music starts, violins and cellos... Paul opens his mouth to sing, but the crowd immediately ignores him, beginning to chatter amongst themselves. Paul begins to sweat as the music continues to play. Braddon and Hydrangea spur him on...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Go on! But the crowd are getting rowdy with themselves. Paul’s nerves are getting the better of him. The emcee stops the music. Starts it again. Braddon chews his thumbnail nervously as Paul begins to sing...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Vesti la giubba, e la faccia infarina. La gente page, e rider vuole qua. E se Arlecchin ti'invola Colombina, ridi, Pagliaccio, e ognun applaudira. No one’s listening. The the music swells and his voice rises above the crowd, not necessarily great, but far above average and very loud...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tramuta in lazzi los spasmo ed il pianto in una smorfia il singhiozzo e ‘1 dolor, Ah! Conversations begin to tail off and people have no choice but to watch and listen to Paul. Braddon can’t believe hi ears...  32.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. -..as Paul launches into the aria.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ridi, Pagliaccio, sul tuo amore infranto! Ridi del duol, che t'avvelena il cor! The song ends and the pub is deathly quiet... Paul realizes he’s made a complete fool of himself...

dialogues.speaker: CHEERING VOICES
dialogues.text: EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - NIGHT As Paul exits the pub with a sulking Braddon and Hydrange and dozens of well-wishers who continue to congratulate Paul and clap him on the back. With a nudge from Hydrangea, Braddon half-heartedly congratulates Paul.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Well done, I suppose. I still reckon the fix was in.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There’s always Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (brightening) Bloody well right.

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good night. They walk off with Braddon singing a scratchy “operatic” Good King Wenceslas. He puts his arm around Hydrangea, bu she shrugs it off. Paul smiles then pulls out an envelope revealing...

dialogues.speaker: A CHECK FOR THREE THOUSAND POUNDS
dialogues.text: He allows himself a two-step jig before tucking the check back inside the envelope when suddenly...  33. He’s jerked roughly backwards by his collar and slammed down onto the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn’t everyone’s favorite circus freak. Hallo Potsy. He and another HOOLIGAN stand over Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Get off me. He tries to stand, but Matthew kicks his ribs. Paul buckles.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: What’ve we got here then? He snatches the envelope from Paul’s hand. Paul lunges fo it, but Matthew sidesteps and Paul’s face hits the curb.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, have a look at this.

dialogues.speaker: HOOLIGAN
dialogues.text: (eying the check) What’s an obese clown doin’ with this kind of dosh?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Give it back. With surprising speed he finds his feet and SMASHES Matthew in the face with all his might... Matthew blinks, but appears otherwise unfazed. He holds u the check...

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: You’re gonna pay for that. He puts the check in his pocket and is about to lay into Paul when suddenly Braddon leaps onto his back, letting out a war cry--

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: May the Flame of Arveron sustain me! Matthew recovers his balance and struggles to free himsel from the clinging, scratching, screaming Braddon, finally dumping him on the pavement next to Paul, who has been held down by the Hooligan.  34.

dialogues.speaker: HOOLIGAN
dialogues.text: Here. He tosses Matthew a brick. Matthew raises it over his head, about to smash Braddon, when it suddenly falls out of his hand as his face goes limp and he falls to the pavement revealing--

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: Standing behind him, wielding a cricket bat. HOOLIGAN (CONT’D) Where the hell’d you get that?

dialogues.speaker: PARTYGOER
dialogues.text: From me. The Hooligan turns to see a group of PARTYGOERS dressed i various sports costumes: football (aka soccer), rugby, cricket, etc.

dialogues.speaker: PARTYGOER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s welcome to it as long as she likes.

dialogues.speaker: RUGBY PLAYER
dialogues.text: Or we can use it for her. The Hooligan runs. Braddon and Paul help each other up.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: All right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeh. You?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (to Hydrangea) You saved us.

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: You’d have done the same for me. (handing the bat back) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (on one knee) I am your servant.

dialogues.speaker: HYDRANGEA
dialogues.text: You already were my servant.  35.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: I was? I was! Yes mistress. Command me, mistress. I’m not worthy. May I lick your ankles please? Hydrangea rolls her eyes as Paul reaches into Matthew’s pocket and removes his check. Matthew’s eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (offers his hand) Truce?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: (whispered) I’m gonna get you for this.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why? Matthew doesn’t answer just stares balefully...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ SMILING FACE
dialogues.text: INT. JULZ’ PARENTS’ HOUSE - DAY As she watches a video on YouTube -- the infamous monkey who scratches his butt then smells his hand and falls out of his tree. She laughs to herself, then answers her RINGING mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Hallo?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s so funny?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (her expression darkens) Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s Paul.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I knew a Paul once.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're cross with me.  36.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Three weeks goes well past playing hard to get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stands on the sunny prow of a vaporetto (water taxi) talking on his mobile.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (actually worried) It's been nineteen days. And I was just following your instructions.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Instructions to what?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You said not to call you until I was settled in Venice. A white, basilica appears behind Paul as the vaporetto merges into the Grand Canal, revealing the splendor of Venice.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You’re joking?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Check your e-mail.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Hang on. She turns to her computer and opens an e-mail from Paul then scrolls through a series of PHOTOS detailing Paul’s last few weeks... Still in his clown-costume, face scraped but smiling with his check. Buying his first suitcase. Boarding an Al Italia plane. Arriving at the Opera School. In his room, smiling beside the window and the view of th city. And finally one taken moments ago aboard the vaporetto.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it.  37.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can hardly believe it myself.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Tell me everything. A BARITONE SINGS A SUSTAINED NOTE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall, GANGLY STUDENT pumps the sound from his lungs, eyes widening as he runs out of steam, but fighting to keep the note alive at the behest of SIGNORA FIORENTINO, their fierce istrutrice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The school is brilliant. It’s in an old sixteenth century palazzo, which floods twice a day with the tide. Paul and the others stand in “Wellies” (galoshes) in a foot of water, singing their hearts out. Even the legs of the piano wear rubber boots.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every morning starts off with four hours of intensive Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul, running late, runs up the first floor stairs... He slows a bit at the second floor... Walks the third... And limps up the fourth, stopping to gasp for air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affords a beautiful view of the city. Paul sits in the back row, drenched in sweat but conjugating verbs out lou with the rest of the class as the LINGUISTIC TEACHER points them out on the board...

dialogues.speaker: CLASS
dialogues.text: Vado, vai, va, andiamo, andate, vanno.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which I find comes quite easily. Paul reaches into his bag for a handkerchief, still speaking the verbs without looking at the board.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the afternoons...  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul stands at a music stand before an ASST. CONDUCTOR who uses his violin to take Paul up and down th scales...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We learn to read music.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing) Do-re-mi-fa-sol-la-la-la... The Asst. Conductor repeats “la” bowing back and forth on the violin until Paul gets it right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: La-la-si-si-siiiiii. The Asst. Conductor winces at the last note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul stands on stage wielding a long baton with padding on the end. GERHARDT, a blonde German student, faces him with a similar baton as a FIT PROFESSOR watches with the rest of the class...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or practice stage combat.

dialogues.speaker: FIT PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: E ora, con molta attenzione. (“And now, very carefully.”) Paul swings and knocks Gerhardt into the orchestra pit.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (moving to help him) I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul’s back is to us as he does something to his face. The MAKEUP TEACHER enters, clapping her hands.

dialogues.speaker: MAKEUP TEACHER
dialogues.text: Ok, mi permetta di vedere voi. (“Okay, let me see you.”)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or basic hair and makeup.  39. The students turn, revealing their faces, made-up for a scene from Madame Butterfly. Paul turns mournfully; he looks more like Clarabell the Clown than a Japanese warlord.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which isn’t my strongest subject. Julz laughs as she scrolls down to a self-portrait photo of Paul, smiling through his disastrous makeup.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Is the food gorgeous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul loads his tray up at the sumptuous buffet table...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Heavenly. Home made pastas. Soups. And the bread... Then turns to face the room, tables filled with chatterin students and teachers...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about the people? Have you made loads of friends? He walks amongst them, spotting an empty chair next to ALESSANDRA, a pretty young Italian woman who smiles briefly at Paul before Gerhardt slips into the chair ahea of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul sits at the end of a table, eating alone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh yes, loads. Everybody’s quite friendly. He hears laughter, but refuses to look up at a group of students, including Gerhardt, laughing at the amount of food on his plate before Alessandra scolds them..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul whispers into his cell phone.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julz walks her Cairn Terrier “Candy Floss” through the hills above the city.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Have you had a gondola ride yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul steps onto a narrow gondola, loses his balance an pitches over the other side, headfirst into the canal.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Uh, no. Haven’t tried that yet.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: And what about the city? Is it breathtaking? Paul comes to a stop and grows silent as he looks up, slightly awestruck, at Titian’s towering masterpiece, “Th Assumption of the Virgin”.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It is. Reveal him standing before the apse of the Basilica Santa Maria Gloriosa Dei Frari, the famous Gothic choir stalls and rood screen behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Do you miss me? INT. PAUL’S SLEEPING CHAMBER - NIGHT Paul lies in bed, talking with the phone plugged into its charger.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Terribly.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Good night.  41. He hangs up. Taking a moment to stare at Julz picture which he’s made the splash-screen on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she and Paul are handed the libretto for La Bohéme as Signora Fiorentino explains that they will be...

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: ...effettuare insieme l' apertura duetto di Mimi e Rodolfo. ("...perform together the opening duet between Rodolfo and Mimi.”) Allesandra smiles at him kindly, though clearly not thrilled. Paul only meets her eyes for a moment, then looks down, flushed and nervous. Gerhardt glowers in the background...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (singing as he reads) O soave fanciulla, o dolce visio di mite circonfusa alba lunar. In te vivo ravviso il sogno. Ch'io vorrei sempre sognar! Signora Fiorentino cuts him off--

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: Non, non, non... Okay, this is um, ‘ow you say, the spark... The moment of love creation. (speaks the words from memory ) O soave fanciulla, o dolce visio, Oh! Lovely girl, oh sweet face. In te vivo ravviso il sogno. Ch'io vorrei sempre sognar! I see you in a dream I will dream forever... Look at her, she is beautiful, non?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (without looking) Yes.  42.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: Look. With your eyes. Paul looks at Allesandra, flushing again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: (to Allessandra) E voi, guarda su di lui. (“And you, look at him.”) Paul offers a hopeful, broken-tooth smile. Her eyes widen at the sight of his teeth. She tries to cover, but he knows what he isn’t...

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Egli 6 molto...eh... Ha un cuore puro, no? ("He is very...um... He has a pure heart, no?”) He looks down again...

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: (Italian accent...) Is okay.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry, I... She takes his face in her hand and turns it so she can really see him. Finally, she smiles...

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: Buono. Dream only of each other... Allow all other thoughts to slip away. She begins to play again on the piano as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul emerges with his suitcase, reading from a guidebook to Lake Como when--

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paolo? She follows him out of the doorway.  43.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are travel for the...fine settimana?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, the weekend. Yes, I’m on my way to Lake Como.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Da soli? ("By yourself?”)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: You want see Italia while you here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: As much as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul stares out the window, watching the DUOMO slid past before they cross the Arno River towards the vineyar encrusted hills of Tuscany. Alessandra sits in the co-pilot seat, talking animatedly above the engine noise with her brother MANU. Paul snaps some pictures. Click. Click.... And on the final picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CANON FIRE, as TEN HORSES AND RIDERS, resplendent in a dazzling array of silks and colors, launch over a startin rope and begin racing around the square, which is filled with THOUSANDS OF SCREAMING SPECTATORS. Paul and Alessandra stand on a balcony overlooking the square, along with the rest of her obviously well-off FAMILY. The horses round a very sharp turn and thunder almost beneath the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: They have race this race since sixteen hundred fifty-six. Two every year. One horse represent one, eh, neighborhood of Siena. My family live Chiocciola, the Snail. We have second most win, but Oca, the Goose have win the most times. The horses circle the square and head for them again. One of the jockeys shoves a competitor off his horse.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you get if you win? Di cosa hai vinto? She thinks a moment, then touches a fist to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Orgoglio.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Orgoglio? (shakes his head) Non capisco. Alessandra leans to her FATHER who turns and smiles at Paul...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Orgoglio means pride. His eyes linger on his daughter, who raises her chin in mock defiance before he kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is your father not proud of you? Paul struggles to respond, then mercifully--

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Qui vengono!. ("Here they come!”) As the horses appear once more and churn towards the finish line. Taking the sharp turn, one of the horses stumbles, tossing the jockey into the crowd which ROARS.. The rest of the horses cross the finish line and the family erupts into CHEERS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weeks of practice later, Paul and Alessandra sing the due together...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: A! To sol commandi, amor! A! To sol commandi, amor! ("Ah! Love, you rule (“Ah! Love, you rule alone!”) alone!”) Fremon nell' anima, Oh! Come dolci scendono, ("Already I state in ("How sweet his spirit,”) praises,”) Le dolcezze estreme, Le sue lusinghe al core... ("the heights of (“enter my heart”) tenderness!”) Tu sol comandi amore! Nel bacio freme amor! ("Love, you alone ("Love trembles at our rule!) kiss!") An orchestra joins the soundtrack, supplanting the piano as the duet continues over the following MONTAGE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and Alessandra are on-stage with a director, who has Paul put his arm around Alessandra. Both are uncomfortable until Paul makes a face and she laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Attenzione!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and Alessandra sing in each others arms. The Asst. Conductor stops them, pushes them apart and has the hold hands.

dialogues.speaker: ASST. CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Prova di nuovo. ("Try it again.”)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More verbs on the board. Paul sits in the back, eyes closed, right hand gently waving/conducting the music fro the scene which we hear on the soundtrack and he hears in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and Alessandra sit together, surrounded by other students but oblivious to all others as they discus a part of the libretto.  46. Unconsciously, she leans an arm on his shoulder as they argue over the same passage. The gesture is lost on Paul, but Gerhardt notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul and Alessandra sing while holding hands, Signore Fiorentino places her hands on the small of their backs and pushes them together.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNORA FIORENTINO
dialogues.text: Molto meglio. ("Much better."”)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alessandra is venting her frustration with all of the bac and-forth...

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Apart. Together. Hold hand. No hold hands. What it matters so much?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well sod them.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: “Sod them?”

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It means... Fino loro asini. ("Up their asses."; Alessandra nods in agreement) Che cosa volete fare? (“What do you want to do?”)

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: I don’ know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final performance... On stage, Paul and Alessandra perform the duet in costume with props and light makeup.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dammi il braccio, mia piccina. ("Give me your arm, my dear.”)

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Obbedisco, signore! ("Your servant, sir.”)  47. The fatal moment comes and Paul takes charge, grabbing he roughly around the waist and pulling her to him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Che m'ami di’ "Tell me you love me.” ¥' His hand gently holds her face, turning it to him just as she had done with him... She almost laughs with joy.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Io t'amo! ("I love you.”)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Amore! Amor! Amor! Amore! Amor! Amor! (Behold! My love! My love!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and Allesandra run into the square, hopping an yelling and bouncing for joy.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Questo 6 stato incredible! ("That was incredible!”)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Siamo i campioni di Venezia! (“We are the champions of Venice!”)

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Di tutto il mondo! (“Of the whole world!”) Allesandra leans in and kisses him. He’s stunned as she pulls away, a new expression on her face before she kisse him again, deeply. His eyes close for a brief moment, before he pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are okay?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, sorry I...

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: What is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing, I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Li ha fatto l’amore, prima, si? (“You have made love before, yes?")

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (beet red at the suggestion) Of course I have, but... Actually I haven't, but that’s not--

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: You have a friend-girl at home?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Um, well, yes. A girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E lei il tuo primo? (“Is she your first one?”)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Lei 6 l'unico. (“She is my only one.”)

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: There is a difference.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There is.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA
dialogues.text: Signore Fiorentino was right. You have a very pure heart. She kisses him firmly on the mouth then smiles at him. Sh turns quickly away and speed dials her cell phone as she walks down the square towards the Basilica.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ciao, Papa. He watches for a moment, then walks the other way. Dials his own phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Roland watches “The Bill” while Yvonne snores softl on the couch beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yeah, hello?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, um hi, Dad.  49.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (to Yvonne) Oy, it’s the eye-talian. (to Paul) What’s good, son?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh you know, lots of studying and singing.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Sounds grand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Actually we, my scene partner and I, we just won a scene competition and--

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Hang on, yer mum’s on the snore again. (adjusts Yvonne's head) Tucked into the sherry again this evening. So did you win anymore pocket money?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, but even better, they told us we get to sing for--

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (listens) Well that’s not bad. He’s no Willie Nelson, mind you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JULZ’ PARENTS’ HOUSE - NIGHT (INTERCUT) Jaw dropping as she hears the news...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Sod off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits on a stone wall, feet dangling over the edge as he watches the lights of the city shimmer over the waters

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s true.  50.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You’re not takin’ the piss?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I swear I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it. Paul! What’re you going to sing?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The duet, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. ‘Course you are.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And thinking of you the entire time.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: There’s a good boy... Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Off the charts.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Maybe open with a joke or something, let the air out a bit.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A joke? In front of-- Have you gone mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arguably the 20th century’s greatest tenor sitting in the first row, dabbing his upper lip with a scented handkerchief while listening to Alessandra sing an aria. Paul watches from the wings as her final note diminishes, applauding along with the audience. Pavarotti is on his feet, eyes devouring Alessandra as he claps. She feels hi ardor and smiles shyly. He beckons her to sit beside him as the Asst. Conductor brings him a teacup of hot water.

dialogues.speaker: ASST. CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Maestro.  51.

dialogues.speaker: PAVAROTTI
dialogues.text: Grazie. He follows Alessandra until she’s next to him, and begins whispering/congratulating her. In the wings, a pair of students stare at Paul.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t want to follow that.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks. He sets his jaw and heads for the center-stage microphone

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good evening. (paralytic fear) It uh, must be bargain night, it only costs one tenner to get in, instead of the usual three...tenors. A smattering of laughter from the crowd. Pavarotti notice him for the first time, but seems less than amused. Paul begins to sing; Rodolfo’s, “Che Gelida Manina", the same aria Paul “conducted” in his room at his parents’ house. He’s singing well, better than we’ve ever heard, eyes tightly closed as he focuses on his breathing and pitch. Finally his eyes open...and what he sees seems to deflate his entire being, even as he continues to sing... HIS POV; where Pavarotti’s full gaze is on Alessandra, wh although flattered, tries to turn his attention to Paul, but to no avail. Finally, the aria ends to polite applause. Ignoring Paul completely, Pavarotti rises to leave until the Asst. Conductor whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: PAVAROTTI
dialogues.text: Ah, si. (turns to Paul; obviously hasn’t heard a word) You inhaled after in te, vivo ravviso il sogno. Rodolfo would not have run out of breath there.  52. Paul is about to speak, but Pavarotti’s back is to him an he’s heading for the door, arm in arm with Alessandra leaving Paul alone on stage, destroyed... Paul stands for a moment, then slowly turns and walks off as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray as ever. A bleak contrast from the vibrancy of Italy

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hates to say it, but I did warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and his parents are just finishing Sunday dinner. Paul stares at his plate.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Put a sock in it, Roland. At least he had the nerve to have a go.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Which has left him where?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks, mum. That was lovely. He takes his plate to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: There's treacle tart and strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’ve got work in an hour. Kisses her goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: When’s that lovely girl coming to visit again?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: See you guys.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oy. Hang on a second. He follows Paul out the front door.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul works the combination lock to his bicycle which is chained to the iron railing at the base of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: There’s an opening down the mill. The wait list’s a kilometer long, but, how'd you like to come work with me?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No thanks, dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It's time to grow up now, son. You've had your great adventure, which is more’n I ever had, but singing didn’t work out so--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I know, dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (grabs his arm) No you bloody well don’t! You think you’re too good to work the mill. Well I’ve got news for you, boy, you’re the one’s not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (after a beat...) I’ll be late. Roland lets him go. Paul pedals out onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Just what the world needs, more bloody mobile phones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul cycles stoically to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul rings up a sale for an ELDERLY COUPLE...

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Right. Now how far away from the house will the telephone actually work?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: As far as you'd like.  54.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: Nonsense. The cord on our last telephone didn’t even reach to the back door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But this hasn’t got a cord.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: We don’t take kindly to bullshitters.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's because you’re bloody insane. He walks away, despite their protestations. Braddon sees this and, after throwing a look at Paul, goes to help the elderly couple.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (shouting) Good afternoon! May I help you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul puts together a cardboard display stand. His phone buzzes. He sees Julz picture with a text message: “?” He taps it, revealing the “text thread"; a series of “?"” and “!" and “?12?!2?!2?!" stretching back over a week. He switches his phone off just as Braddon enters.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Not quite the pinnacle of customer service, I’d say.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Perhaps you’re confused...see you’re the diffident, jolly one, whilst I’m the edgy, mysterious bloke with bubbling cauldrons of danger and pizzazz.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It’s bad as all that is it? (off Paul’s look) Right... Come on. Pulls Paul to his feet.  55.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Desperate times call for naked dancers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and Braddon sit at the edge of the stage, framed between the legs of a gyrating dancer. Braddon’s smile is ear to ear as his head bobs and swivel to the music... Paul still looks miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Braddon follows Paul out of the club where they unchain their bicycles from the pole holding up the marquee.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: There you are. All better now?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (not at all...) Yes, loads. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: D'you know, I think I could headline there. The first step on my career to pop superstardom.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's your dream is it?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: When I was younger. Before x-box payments and chest hair and whatnot.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You haven’t got chest hair.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: ‘Course I do. Gallons of it... It’s just very blonde.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right... And what about now?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Dreams? Honestly?  56.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If possible.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Be nice to have a family of my own. Oh and one day go to New Zealand. Hire a car and do the Lord of the Rings tour. See where the hobbits live.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. The lower your expectations, I find, the greater your general level of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (agreeing) Right. They pedal off down the road...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Then again, a threesome wouldn’t be the worst thing that could happen.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Obviously. EXT. PAUL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT Paul hops off his bike and pushes it towards the entrance where Julz stands with several large suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How did you--?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Mum drove me. She waited as long as she could but...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right. Um... Sorry, did we?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You stopped ringing me back.  57.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Playing hard to get again?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just feeling sorry for myself.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Always flattering on a man.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He didn’t even know I was there.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) He’s a celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He may be a great singer, but anyone that famous can’t be anything but an ass of intergalactic proportions.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s lovely to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m an enormous idiot.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You are. And?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m truly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m an ass of intergalactic proportions?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Well said. Lucky for you, I’ve decided to take you up on your offer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You have?  58.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Em, which offer exactly?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Seeing as your self-esteem’s down the loo, and we’re never going to have a proper go at a relationship living so far apart, I decided to accept your offer to...move in together. To give it, you know, a proper go. Nothing ventured...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing gained.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: So...? Paul stares dumbfounded... Realizes she’s hanging herself out there for him...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh right! Yes, of course. That would be, um...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (smiling) And?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m an ass of intergalactic proportions.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Yes, though there’s still hope for you. He reaches down to carry one of her suitcases but can’t even lift it off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I packed a few things.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We may need a bigger flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immense seawall jutting out into the gray water. Surfers and wind surfers brave the cold waters alongside as Paul and Julz walk hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: So, maybe the joke wasn’t the best idea.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He was so goggly-eyed over Alessandra, I could’ve pulled me trousers down and he wouldn’t’ve noticed.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That beautiful was she?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Very. (realizing) But in that Italian sort of way; all dark and... Not my type at all.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Mmmm. It’s not the end of the world, you know. There are loads of other operas. They reach the end of the wall and sit, legs dangling ove the waves.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not for me. I went to Italy to... Somewhere in there I got a bit outside myself. Just because I won some silly competition, I started to think... Anyway, I’ve got my expectations well back in line.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Really, I’m done with singing.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: So you say.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m serious, Julz.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I believe you, darling, but I know better...  60.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh do you?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: The first time we ever chatted on-line. Do you remember how you introduced yourself?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: As Paul, I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
