dialogues.text: You said you were a singer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It was more impressive than saying I worked in the produce department at Tescos.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I don’t care where you work. I care that you're happy, and that you’ll always love me back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (she just said she loves me...) I will, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Good. (standing) Besides, as I recall, you promised you’d sing for me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: “Someday.”

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Someday when?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (singing) I love you as you love me, in the evening and the morning,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, stone church at the heart of Llangynwydd, an ancient hilltop village, one of the oldest Christian settlements in all of Wales.  61.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nor was there a day when you and I did not share our troubles. Guests arrive in suits and dresses, picking their way across the grassy cemetery which surrounds the church wit eroded headstones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chapel is nearly full of FRIENDS AND FAMILY. Paul stands alone before the altar.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when we shared them, they became easier to bear; Everyone stands as Julz appears, resplendent in a white dress with veil, escorted by her FATHER. Paul sees her and begins to choke up. She smiles at him, telling him he’s going to be fine...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You comforted me in my distress, and I wept in your laments. Julz reaches the front, kisses her father after he lifts her veil and stands to face Paul before the altar. The VICAR gives his benediction and they exchange rings.. Paul finally loses his composure and Julz kisses him to pull him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Therefore, may God’s blessing be upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul sings the English translation of Beethoven’s Ich Liebe Dich (I Love You) to Julz before everyone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You, my life’s joy. God protect you, keep you for me, and protect and keep us both. Now it’s Julz turn to cry. He kisses her as everyone stands and applauds, many people wiping their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (through tears) So you can sing after all.  62. Braddon is a disaster as rivers of tears stream from both eyes. He turns to hug Hydrangea who bears him up for a moment, before reaching back and removing his hand from her ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Julz whirl and twirl at the center of the cramme dance floor. Finally, the song ends...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: D’you want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Champagne please.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Back in a flash, Mrs. Potts.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Why thank you, Mr. Potts. He weaves through the crowd to the bar where Roland is holding court with a coterie of his friends from the mill

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hello, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (far from sober) Paul, you remember Charlie and Bill from down the mill. (he and Bill share a laugh at the rhyme) And this here’s Matthew, the new chap. Paul stops as he sees Matthew, his nemesis grinning coldl at him. Matthew offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Paul and I went to school together. Felicitations an’ all that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (tentative) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll sing us a pretty song as well? The others laugh hysterically.  63.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe you’1l get knocked out by a girl again. Matthew goes cold. He’d love to take a swing at Paul but knows better. Instead, he just smirks portentously until Paul turns away from them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) A champagne and a lager, please.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Matthew’s only joking, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How could you invite him?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I paid for half this bender, I can invite who I like. Besides, he’s a good lad, and a hard worker. The implication being that Paul is not.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (getting his drinks) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with Matthew? They’re interrupted by Paul’s former Choirmaster (from th opening montage).

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: I say, young man. I don’t know where you found it, but your vocal control has improved by light years.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks very much, sir. I was in Italy for a while, but I don’t really sing--

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: I’m commissioned to conduct a production of Aida in Bath. And you, sir, would make a wonderful Radames.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Really?  64.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No no, he’s all finished with that nonsense. He’1ll be getting an honest job, earning an honest wage.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: There’s no pay, I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’ll take it.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Bloody hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door handle turns, then flips back to its original position... After a beat, it turns again, finally opening as Paul and Julz, she in his arms, spill into the room...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: No, no, on the bed. I couldn’t stand another second in these torture devices. He deposits her on the bed and helps her remove her shoes to her great relief.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s lovely. I shall never dance again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Famous last words.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Reminds me of someone I just married.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The lead tenor in Aida. I still can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: This is the best wedding day ever... Which reminds me. She jumps to her feet and opens a cabinet, revealing a beautiful antique gramophone and a mylar bag which she hands to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What's this?  65.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I got sparklies-- (flashes her rings) --this makes it even.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not unless you'll be paying this off for the next ten years.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Open it. He removes a thin sleeve bearing a photo of--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Puccini.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That’s an original recording from the premiere at... (grabs a slip of paper) ...-La Scala, Milan on April twenty-fifth--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nineteen twenty six. Conducted by Toscanini himself, but how--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: E-bay, how else? She places the disc on the gramophone and sets the needle... The tenor, Miguel Fleta, begins to sing...

dialogues.speaker: MIGUEL FLETA
dialogues.text: Nessun Dorma.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: This was recorded before Pavarotti was even born. She sits on the bed next to him and kisses him as the ari unfolds...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is he saying?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nessun dorma. None shall sleep. Calaf has been rejected by the woman he loves, a princess. Kisses him again as she starts removing her dress.  66.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What’s it always have to be a princess? Why can’t checkout girls have great love stories written about them? (re: her dress) Give us a hand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If she can guess his name by dawn, she gets to call off the wedding and chop his head off.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I like that bit.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (translating) -.-my secret is hidden within me. None will know my name. On your mouth I will say it when the light shines. She removes her undergarments and stands before him, naked. PAUL (CONT’D) And my kiss will dissolve the silence that makes you mine.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: So kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’ve never done this before. She nods, knowingly, then helps him remove his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: So what happens to them?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, she tortures all of his friends who refuse to reveal his name, but when dawn comes, he kisses her and she falls--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: --madly in love with him. She pulls him down onto the bed as we linger on the gramophone and... FADE TO BLACK.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where an impressive Egyptian temple backdrops the stage filled with PERFORMERS in ancient Egyptian and Ethiopian costumes. Paul appears at the center of the company, carrying his own with great gusto. The Choirmaster conducts the orchestra, very pleased with what he hears. A pastiche of music from the opera plays over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hangs a poster for the opera in the front window, indicating two weeks until the premiere. Welcomes a CUSTOMER with a smile and spring in his step and begins discussing various phone options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul rides his bicycle home, arms spread wide as he belts out a soaring high C5 note. A passing car honks in reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where they sit over dinner, talking happily. She says something flirty and he dives over the table to kiss her, not a trace of shyness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sings the aria Celeste Aida. A DIRECTOR offers him some stage direction, which Paul executes beautifully. At the end, he takes a deep breath, scratches his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul makes another attempt at stage makeup, but he’s stil hopelessly crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and the other leads sing into microphones as the Choirmaster and DIRECTOR huddle with an ENGINEER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul leaves through the Artists’ Entrance, laughing with his fellow performers. He passes a flyer taped to a streetlight pole: “Two Days To Premiere.”  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul enters the empty store.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hallo? Brad? He hears sniffling in the back. Passes through the curtai to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --find Braddon, dressed in full elfish wizard regalia taking slugs from a bottle of bright green alcohol in between chest-heaving sobs.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s happened?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It’s over. I’m finished with the lot of it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your ears are coming off?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: What? Oh. Off Paul’s gesture, he pulls his half-hanging, pointy elvish ears off and throws them in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Shall I leave you alone?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: So there I am, right in the heart of Morgol Forest, having blasted my way through an army of Hobgoblins using a spectacular array of spellcraft. When whom do I see with her tongue down the throat of some bloody hippogriff?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: As if unicorns and hippogriffs could ever be together. You can look it up, it’s genetically impossible!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I believe you.  69.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (offering the bottle) Creme de Menthe?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The show opens tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Rejected again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: All right. Just a nip then. He takes a small swig, wincing as it goes down, holds his hand to his side which burns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julz enters, wearing her pharmacy uniform.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Hal-oo? Radames? Wherefor art thou? She sets some shopping bags down on the tiny kitchen counter. Sees the television’s on, so he must be home...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul? Suddenly, Paul emerges from the bathroom, doubled over an clutching his side in enormous pain...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors fly open as a team of EMS workers wheel Paul in on a gurney with Julz following nervously behind them. Dr. Thorpe is almost completely gray.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: What’ve we got? (recognizes Paul) What, you again?  70.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bloody Creme de Menthe.

dialogues.speaker: EMS WORKER
dialogues.text: Lower abdominal pain. Fever. Nausea.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Appendix. Triage two, please. (to Paul) You might qualify for our frequent flier membership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Julz waits with Yvonne as Dr. Thorpe enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Well, the good news is, it’s got nothing to do with the Creme de Menthe.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: And the not good news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dr. Thorpe flips on a lightboard, revealing an x-ray o Paul’s abdomen.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: The appendix hasn’t ruptured, yet.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Thank god.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Yes definitely, although it’1l have to come out I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: How’s four o’clock suit you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: His opera opens tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Oh, fantastic. Which one?  71.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aida.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Oh, is that the Madonna one? Wonderful performance that. I’m afraid singing’s quite out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m the lead. They’re counting on me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: An appendectomy is invasive surgery. If we leave it in it’s sure to rupture and he could die. Take it out and any great effort, like singing for instance, you’re liable to burst the stitches and cause irreparable damage to the kidneys or diaphragm.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How irreparable?

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: It's possible that singing...wouldn’t be possible.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s that then. Paul and Julz exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit up with banners and posters displaying the names of the cast including Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul warms up his vocal chords while bathing them i the output from a clothing steamer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Neeee, nayyyy, nahhhh, noooo, nuuuu. (up an octave) Neeee, nayyyy, nahhhh, noooo, nuuuu. He removes his shirt revealing an enormous post-surgical bandage across his stomach.  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Julz, Yvonne and Roland take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It’s right stupid, if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Do shut up, Roland. The least we can do is support him, no matter how insufferably daft he’s being.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I’1l thank you both not to talk about my husband that way.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Yes, you’re right, dear. It’s just so-- Really, why can’t he just put himself first for a change?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Because then he'd be just like everyone else. And he’s not is he?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (kisses her cheek) You’re a very lovely girl. She takes Julz’ hands in hers...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) I’d trade both me ears for a pint about now. Despite his bluster, he’s just as nervous as they are. Th Choirmaster takes his place in the orchestra pit and the lights go down and the Prelude begins to play... The trio watch nervously as... Paul appears on-stage, resplendent in the costume of an Egyptian military commander. He sings his opening lines, discussion with RAMFIS, the high priest.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: His first aria’s right at the top. Ramfis exits the stage and Paul steps forward... The TRANSLATION CRAWL appears on-screen, above the stage.  73.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL TRANSLATION
dialogues.text: Celeste Aida, forma divina. Heavenly Aida, divine form. Mistico serto di luce e Mystical garland of light fior. Del mio pensiero tu and flowers. You are queen sei regina. Tu di mia vita of my thoughts. You are the sei lo splendor. splendor of my life. Julz mouths the words with him, squeezing the life out of Yvonne’s hands...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s doing it. He’s all right. They clutch each other, while Roland stares transfixed at the stage in utter disbelief. He looks around at others i the audience to see if they’re equally stunned then is physically moved as Paul hits a powerful high note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul comes off stage during the transition, hands on his stomach and wincing in pain as he waits beside a stagehand.

dialogues.speaker: STAGEHAND
dialogues.text: Y’‘ okay?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine.

dialogues.speaker: STAGEHAND
dialogues.text: Sounds bloody marvelous.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (appreciative but hurting) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene II is underway, the PRIESTS and PRIESTESSES of the temple pray to the spirit Phtha... And then something seems wrong. A priest repeats his line...

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? One of the other priests steps up and sings Paul’s line.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That’s supposed to be-- (then she’s up) Excuse me please.  74. Pushing her way through to the aisle, then running out to the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julz runs around to the Artists’ Entrance where an ambulance is just pulling up.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Oh God. Paul emerges, tunic soaked with blood from his broken stitches, arms around the shoulders of the Stagehand and BACKGROUND PLAYER as the EMS WORKERS take him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (seeing Julz) I’m okay. I’m okay. Yvonne arrives, followed by Roland who carries a lager in a paper bag as Paul’s loaded into the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What did I tell ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul lies unconscious as a team of SURGEONS operate on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sleeps with Julz curled around him. She whispers as she strokes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: They found tumors on your adrenal glands. I know you’re frightened, and not singing again is more than you can bear, but I just want you to know that if you never sing again, I'll do everything in my power to fill that void with as much happiness as I can possibly manage. She closes her eyes and holds him tighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - DAY As Julz’ car pulls up and she runs around, opening the passenger side door for Paul, who looks uncomfortable and miserable.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want to wait in the car? Paul shakes his head. Whispers that he has to go to the loo, even talking clearly hurts...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That you can do on your own. INT. FINNEGAN’S PUB - DAY As Paul enters to an uproarious--

dialogues.speaker: SURPRISE
dialogues.text: The entire opera company is there along with his Yvonne and Braddon. They all begin to sing, opera-style...

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For he’s a jolly good fellow. For he’s a jolly good fellow. For he’s a jolly good fell-ow! Which nobody can deny!

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (“auditioning”) Can de-nyyyyyyyyyy- Ends in a coughing fit. Paul is touched and perplexed as the Choirmaster steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: For bravery and the rather thick-headed willingness to sacrifice himself for his fellow man, and woman, and those undecided... Bath Opera is proud to present you with the first Golden Appendix award, in hopes for a clean bill of health, and a speedy return to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Hip-hip.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY
dialogues.text: Hooray!  76.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Hip-hip.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY
dialogues.text: Hooray! Paul accepts the Golden Appendix award, an amorphous lump of clay painted gold, and starts to speak softly.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYBODY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s that? Speak up then. He smiles bashfully then leads into Julz ear, whispering.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You've no idea how much this means to me. My whole life I never even had one true friend, much less an entire company. From the bottom of my heart, thank you. And much as I'd love to continue talking through my wife, you'll all be very upset with me if I don’t use the loo immediately. Everybody cheers as he hustles quickly off towards the back. Drinks are ordered and the Choirmaster hugs Julz.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: So how's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He’s heartbroken, of course. Time will tell.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIRMASTER
dialogues.text: (hand her a cassette) This’ll guarantee he can have his voice back whenever he likes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul looks in the mirror as he checks the fresh bandages around his mid-section, poking and prodding them. So far, so good. He licks his lips and, building his determination, tries to hum a single note but nearly collapses in pain. He hears the front door open...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Hal-oo? I've got some lovely vichyssoise.  77. He hurriedly buttons his shirt, but not in time...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Freeze, Jack! (he drops his hands) How many times--? Would you enjoy an infection then? Perhaps another surgery, like Dr. Thorpe warned you about? (he hangs his head; pouting) Didn't think so. Help me with me groceries. He kisses her cheek then takes several plastic shopping bags off her hands and carries them into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul helps a seven year-old GIRL and her MUM program her first mobile phone. He’s lost several stone of weight and his hair’s shorter indicating the passage of some time...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Or you might like the dancing frog ringtone, which is quite popular.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: What kind of an idiot wants a dancing frog on their phone? Suddenly, a DANCING FROG ringtone is heard. Braddon runs from the back and answers his flashing phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (suddenly black...) Yeah? What up B-Dog. For reals? Yo, that’s off the chain, yo, yo.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (to the girl) Excellent point.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Much love. Mad respect. Peace out.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were a rapper.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s just my boss up at HQ in Croydon. He’s mah boyy.  78.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You don’t look African.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: The outside may be vanilla darlin’, but the inside’s chocolate through and through.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Have you got a large penis? Braddon’s about to respond, but a murderous look from the girl’s mum freezes his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul comes in to find Braddon doing a pathetic breakdance celebration.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s got you all chuffed up?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: I just got a raise.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s fantastic, well done. (surprised...) If you don’t mind me asking, um, why exactly?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: What d’you mean, why? I’m a stupendous Manager. I feel a sudden urge to sing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, please don’t. Actually, no offense or anything, and this is no reflection on my feelings towards you personally, but you’re actually kind of a crap manager, if you really look at it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Well you that, and I know that, but... If you must know, our little shop had the highest sales in all of Wales over the last two quarters. (singing) The highest sales in all of Waaaaaaaales!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful! (realizes...) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You mean over the six months since I got back from surgery?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Yes, but--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: During which time I actually kept the shop open between the hours of ten and six?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Well yes but--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And put my singing on hold because--

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Because you’re a sissy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) And put the ads in all the local papers? And--

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Alright, blimey. You’re getting a raise as well.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Couple’a quid an hour.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You serious?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (singing again) The highest sales in--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: --all of WAAAAAAAAAALES! So powerful Braddon takes an inadvertent step back and trips over an unopened box. He glares up at Paul from the

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Bastard!  80.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (stunned) I can sing.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: These cost me ten pound down the--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can sing! I can--

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Don’t!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (whispering at first) The highest sales in-- (belting it out)

dialogues.speaker: --ALL OF WALES
dialogues.text: Braddon goes down again... INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT BUILDING, LOBBY - DAY Where Julz removes the mail from the postbox, and flips through as she heads for the stairs. Suddenly she stops a a letter and tears it open, reading hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Dear Mrs. Potts we are in receipt of your cassette...and would very much like to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul, strapping on his bicycle helmet, answers his mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Julz?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ PAUL
dialogues.text: You'll never guess what-- You'll never guess what--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can sing.  81.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, I can sing. Now. Again.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Oh, thank god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul coasts out of the parking lot on his bicycle, pumpin his fists in the air.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Promise you won't be cross with me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cross is the last thing I’m going be with you when I get home.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You don’t know the half of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various shots of Paul singing “The Highest Sales in All o Wales” with both fists thrust in the air as he pedals through the rolling hills with their ancient stone walls.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’ve you done, Julz?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you remember the cast recording of Aida, before it opened?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Julie-Ann?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, I made some copies of it and sent them ‘round to a few agents in London.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Someone had to do something to get you off your bum.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But, what if it turned out I couldn’t sing?  82.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Remember when I first met your mum and dad and told them what a wonderful singer you were.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Load of bollocks as far as you knew at the time.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I believed in you... And it turns out I’m not the only one. You’ve got an appointment tomorrow in London with a music agent who thinks you’re quite good.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You’re joking.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: YAHOOOOO
dialogues.text: Paul WIPES FRAME, riding away from us down a mountain road, whooping as he goes until--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Julz is seen walking angrily/terrified towards the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks up to the nurses’ station.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (stammering) I’m um... My husband, Paul... There was an accident?  83.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: Hallo, Julz. Right this way... You know we're thinking of building you two your own entrance. He sees she’s only barely holding it together. Puts his arm around her and leads her into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul lies encased in a plaster cast that covers his upper torso and left arm which juts out in front of him a a right angle, supported by a metal pole. His face is cut and stitched in several places and supported by a thick neck brace.

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: His collar bone’s shattered and he’s got severe whiplash.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: But he’s not--

dialogues.speaker: DR. THORPE
dialogues.text: He won’t be running a marathon anytime soon, but he’s not in any great danger.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (slightly drugged) Hello, Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (kissing Paul’s face) You have got to stop doing this to me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I was singing again.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Go to sleep. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where a radio plays a commercial for BRITAIN’S GOT TALENT “searching for the next singing, dancing or other talent sensation” and a hundred thousand pounds to the winner.  84. The ad is followed by Andrea Bocelli’s rendition of Con t Partiro. Paul reaches out and switches the station to Coldplay. He’s reclining on an orthopedic chair while surfing the internet for debt consolidation information. He’s gained weight again and his hair is unkempt. The doorbell rings and he hoists himself to his feet with a grunt, and shuffles his way over to the door which he opens to reveal Braddon.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Are you Paul Potts?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Perfect, then you’re just the man I’m looking for. Paul lets him in.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: (looking around) More than you I’d say. Christ, how much moping can one man do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not moping. I’m just...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Not doing anything... Like working.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I told you, I’m still not up to-- Braddon tosses Paul a Car Phone Warehouse “Manager” name tag and a set of keys.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Too late.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Feast your eyes upon the South Western District Sub-Manager for Carphone Warehouse.  85.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You are not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul shuffles along beside Braddon as they walk along the road outside the mill and its towers of belching steam.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’d you do, cook the books again?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: I’m quite capable of honest advancement, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Somebody died?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: The former South Western District Sub- Manager. Cholera. On safari or something. Anyway, I start Monday in Croydon.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (fumbling with the keys) Honestly, I don’t really think I’m up to it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Bollocks. You’re on disability for over a year, they’ve cut up most of your credit cards and poor Julz--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how many pills I have to take every day? I didn’t choose this!

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Believe that life is worth living, and your belief will help create the fact.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Henry James...or Mighty Mouse, I’m not sure which. They arrive at Braddon’s new/used motorcycle, barely standing what with the various cases and bags strapped to it at all angles...  86.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’re leaving now?

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Commerce waits for no man. Gonna miss you, laddie. You’re me best mate. There, I said it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Rubbish. Uber-district-sub-under-managers don’t have time for such emotions.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: It's District Sub-Manager, and I'll be poppin’ round every now and again to check up on ya. Make sure there’s no funny business goin’ on.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You couldn’t spot funny business if it was tattooed to your eye-lids.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: You know that, and I know that, but--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Give us a ring when you’re settled.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: I’m told the women in Croydon shag like wild ferrets.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Might want to think about a rabies shot. (Braddon considers this before they hug) Thanks, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: Give the missus a good squeeze for me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, but I’1l1 tell her you said bye. Braddon kicks-starts the motorcycle which ROARS powerfull to life...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: May the-- ...then stalls immediately. He tries to start it again...

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May the-- Crap. May the--  87.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bit more clutch, maybe. Braddon scoffs until the bike roars to life.

dialogues.speaker: BRADDON
dialogues.text: May the-- The bike suddenly jerks forwards, zooming him out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: --flame of Arveron sustain you. He watches Braddon’s motorbike teeter away down the road, before turning and shuffling back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in through the windows as the lights come on inside. Paul walks to the window, looking up at the gray Welsh sky that’s reflected in the glass and on his face a he pulls the chain on the neon “OPEN” sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to face the store which is, predictably, in shambles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Julz waits patiently at the front door as Paul locks up.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Good first day?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (unenthusiastically) Yeah. Brilliant. She walks slowly as he shuffles along the arcade of shops

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Any luck with the hiring?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (distracted) Only a few applicants. Be better once we get an ad going in the paper.  88. She follows his eyes as they linger on a display in the music store window, a life-size stand up of Palacido Domingo, promoting a new album. She takes his hand as he looks away, sensing her pity but not wanting to talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and Julz sit over baskets of skate & chips wit Yvonne and Roland.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: ...pressure caused a the number five furnace to literally split down the side.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Oh my lord.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Bunch’a the molten steel got out. Eighteen hundred Celsius, damn near melted half the machinery before we got the fire out.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Was anyone hurt?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Billy Watkins almost got incinerated, but lucky for him Paul’s friend Matthew managed to hoist him out of the pit before the soup got ‘im.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He’s not my friend.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: He’s a bloody hero.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good for him.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (diverting...) Anything exciting down at the shop?  89.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Hang on, love. (to Paul) What ever disagreements you had when you were in school, don’t you think it’s time you--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Disagreements? Do you see that, Dad? He shows him a scar starting just at the edge of his hairline.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's from a bicycle chain, wrapped around his fist while two of his droogs held me down. I was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don’t remember that happening.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What was it you told me, dad? Maybe if I lost a few stone, I wouldn’t provoke them.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Look just because you’ve had a run of bad luck... You’ve had plenty of opportunities to sort yourself out.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (not backing down) All those years wasted on that singing nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You’re not singing now, are you?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Roland.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You’re wife’s working two jobs to pay your hospital bills and all you do is mope about.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: He’s back at Car Phone Warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that’s a step in no direction, isn’t it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We may not have a lot in common, but you’re my son and I’ve never been prouder of you than when I heard you perform in Bath. That was heroic. You want to give it up, anyone would understand after what you've been through...but you haven’t have you. You’re afraid to sing, but you’re afraid to move past it. That’s not life. Julz and Yvonne stare at their hands, trying to hide thei agreement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits at the computer, pouting while working on their pitiful finances while Julz watches Coronation Street on ITv.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Three hundred pounds paid, another thirty- seven thousand to go.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: We'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How do you know.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: It's just money, isn’t it. As long as we’ve got each other.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And Coronation Street.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. Paul turns back this his computer as a series of pop-up advertisements appear.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bloody pop-ups. He closes several of them, then stops on the last, an ad for Britain’s Got Talent.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (attention on the TV) What’s that darling?  gl.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing, just... There’s this new contest. A hundred-thousand quid to the best performer in Britain.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Robbie Williams’1l win that for sure.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's for amateurs.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Too bad you don’t sing. You’d’ve won it laughing. Paul stares at the window then minimizes it... After a moment, he brings it back up on the screen and starts entering his details...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s cheaper than a lottery ticket.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Are you seriously giving it a go?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’re right. I’m such a plonker.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: No, do it!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's stupid. He moves to close the window when--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Heads or tails?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ay?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (with a 50p coin) Heads you forget all about it, tails you push send.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Julz.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I was at work today, chatting with my girls, who asked after you as they do now and again. And do you know what I said?  92.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That I’m a tiger in bed?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Aside from that... I said I can’t really say how my husband is, because, to be completely honest, I can’t remember the last time he laughed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Maybe my dad’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Sod your dad. What do you want? Paul takes this in...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Heads. Julz flips the coin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul lies on his side, Julz nuzzled up behind him a he’s lost in thought...

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I was just thinking... It would be nice to sing for an audience again. I think I could let it go after that. He looks over at the bedside table where the 50p coin sits, showing the profile head of Queen Elizabeth II.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Probably won’t even get an audition anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (drifting into sleep...) Mmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the 50p coin reflects the sliver of sunlight into Paul’s closed eyes, which snap open.  93. He frowns at the coin and jostles the bedside table, trying to shift it out of the sunlight. The coin doesn’t move. Paul reaches out for his clock-radio and tries to use it to shove the coin aside and instead ends up knocking everything off the table, waking Julz.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What’s happening!?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul looks over a job application. He’s smartened u and has the shop back in order.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right, so where you answered “maybe” to the question, “Have you completed secondary school?” would you care to elaborate on that? A PUNK GIRL, with a huge pink mohawk and numerous piercings both in her face and her leather jacket, stares at him vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: PUNK GIRL
dialogues.text: Not really, no.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right. (as the phone rings) Just a second. Car Phone Warehouse. This is Paul speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Julz is taking off her coat.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Is this Paul Potts the singer?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m a bit busy now, darling.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Oh right. Too busy to come with me to Cardiff on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Cardiff, what’s in--  94. As Julz hits play on their answer-phone. The voice of a FEMALE PRODUCER is heard.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PRODUCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mister Potts. Is that right? Paul Potts. Oh my. Sorry, I’m calling from Britain’s Got Talent. We’ve received your application and .mp3 audition and-- Paul listens as he watches the Punk Girl remove a safety pin from her nostril... He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (as the message ends...) Well?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Um, brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This Friday?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: That’s what the lady said.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s not nearly enough time.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Well, that’s all the time you’ve got. See you at seven. Paul hangs up, terrified. He turns to see the Punk Girl i using the safety pin to pick at a large scab on her forearm.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Start Friday? The Punk Girl looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT BUILDING, STAIRCASE - DAY Where we hear Paul long before we finally see him, huffin and puffing and sweating his way up the stairs until he collapses in a heap halfway up the final steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The largest city in Wales is seen in the distance as Julz drives Paul and Yvonne. INT. JULZ’ CAR - DAY Where Yvonne sits in the back seat reading over materials regarding the show, including photos of the judges, AMAND HOLDEN, PIERS MORGAN, and SIMON COWELL.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Right, so these are the judges. (sees Simon smiling) Now he looks like a very warm fellow. It says here, the auditions are going to broadcast live on ITV. Did you know that Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (blanching) You’re joking?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (suddenly nervous for him) Shouldn't you be rehearsing or something?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t. No telling what shape my vocal cords are in after so long. Better to just warm up properly then see what comes out rather than risk overdoing it now.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Right... But then how will you know if you sound any good?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Trust me, babe. At best it’1l be crap.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: As long as you’re confident. He smiles nervously, staring out the window as the terror builds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where THOUSANDS have queued up outside the building, hoping for a walk-on audition. The queue seems endless as they drive past...

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Are you meant to wait in that line?  96.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think maybe this was a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (putting her hand on his) They liked Paul’s song so much, he doesn’t have to audition. Paul watches the faces blur past as his apprehension grows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Paul and the ladies are escorted through a swarm of people by a harried PRODUCTION ASSISTANT brandishing a clipboard and walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: --complete cock-up I’m afraid. All of a sudden Simon “has” to be on a plane to Dubai at three so everything’s been bumped up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just as long as I’ve got time to warm up.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: How long do you need?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes should be plenty.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Take away ten minutes from that and you're perfect.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean I’m on in--

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: S’actually about nine and a half minutes, yeh? (handing passes to Julz and Yvonne) These should get you seats in the reserve section. Right through there. (to Paul) You're with me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (turns to Julz) This was a mistake.  97.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: You can warm up in ten minutes, can’t you?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Nine and a half.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: We really must get--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (to Julz) It’s been proven I’m not good enough. Let’s just go home and--

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Good enough for who? Bloomin’ Pavarotti? If you want a final go on-stage, then here’s your chance. Or, if you really want to have a go at being a professional singer, here’s your chance.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: (into her walkie) We may have a problem. (to Paul) Nine minutes, yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Eight forty-five, actually. (off their looks) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: What would Toscanini do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the Production Assistant leads Paul to the wings.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Just wait here for the pre-interview.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Pre-interview?

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Who are you? Why’re you here? Just take a few minutes. Back in a sec.  98. She hustles off leaving him standing amidst several other performers: a MICHAEL JACKSON wanna-be, a JUGGLER and a WOMAN with a HOWLING TERRIER. Paul realizes he’s not in Kansas anymore and starts to warm up, just as a CAMERA CREW barrels in along with the hosts ANT and DEC who are fed background by the Productio Assistant.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --works at Car Phone Warehouse. He’s married. Teeth are all bashed up and sings opera.

dialogues.speaker: ANT
dialogues.text: Opera?

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Paul, this is Ant and Dec. Three minutes. The camera light comes on and blinds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where a YOUNG GIRL over-performs “It's a Hard Knock Life” on-stage. Julz and Yvonne are led to their seats, high in the nose-bleed section.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: This is the reserve section?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (screaming into the phone) I don’t know if there’s a delay, just get your puckered old bum to a telly, do you hear me?! (hangs up; to Julz) Honestly! If he weren’t such an exquisite lover, I’d have to leave the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stares nervously through a gap in the curtain at the myriad cameras and the enormous crowd as the imposing judges: PIERS, AMANDA and SIMON critique the contestant before him, a YOUNG GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: That was absolutely excruciating. It was like a little kitten had been trapped in a box and was shrieking for its mum to come rescue it... Only mum’s too busy plugging her ears, isn’t she?  99. The young girl walks off the stage, failing to hold back her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julz and Yvonne sit way in the back.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: He isn’t very nice at all.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: I think Paul’s next. The lights come down as an image of Paul appears, projected on a screen.

dialogues.speaker: ANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For the next contestant, the world of showbiz seems a million miles away. It’s Paul. A mobile phone salesman from South Wales. We Paul watches the young girl lets out a huge SOB as she runs to her MOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: (to Paul) I wouldn’t want to follow that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (on-screen) By day, I sell mobile phones. Paul walks away from the Stage Manager, trying not to hyperventilate as he passes behind a pair of PRODUCERS.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Who’s this chap?

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Joke contestant. The chubby opera fellah.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Oh, he’1ll be good for a laugh. Paul hangs his head. Finally, the truth of it...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (in the interview) By day, I sell mobile phones. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My dream was to spend my life doing what I was born to do. He sighs, giving up once and for all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is seen on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Confidence...is...has always been sort of a difficult thing for me... I always find it a little difficult to be completely confident in myself.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Oh dear. She starts texting furiously into her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stage Manager runs up to Paul...

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You’re on. Motions for him to take the stage, but Paul doesn’t move, his eyes find the exit door.

dialogues.speaker: DEC
dialogues.text: Paul Potts everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julz sends the text then prays to everything she can thin of. The audience begins to murmur. Julz senses his hesitation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul’s checks his buzzing phone... Reads the text from Julz: NOTHING VENTURED, NOTHING GAINED. PS. PAVAROTTI’S AN ASSHOLE. LOVE CAMERON. Paul smiles...  101.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: (as a mantra) One foot, then the other. And then Paul steps self-consciously onto the stage, walk to the microphone, not looking at anything, keeping his teeth hidden...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. I’m Paul. Several thousand PEOPLE look on from the audience. His entire physicality seems to apologize for being there.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: What are you here for today, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: To sing opera. Simon and Piers exchange an “oh crap” look. The audience murmurs, this is going to be terrible. Paul tries to ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Okay. Ready when you are. The opening strains of Nessun Dorma begin. Simon leans back and sighs, putting his pen in his mouth, wishing Pau were back in Wales. Paul stares at a point above the audience until he finds Julz, which allows him to shut everything else out...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nessun dorma. Nessun dorma. Simon looks up, chews his pen, suddenly interested as Pau begins the first crescendo...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma il mui mistero e chiuso in me. Suddenly the audience cheers. Julz and Yvonne react, clutching each other again... Amanda takes a deep breath, stunned as are Simon and Piers.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Il nome mui nessun spara, No no. Dilegua, o notte! Tramontate, stelle! Tromontate stelle! All'alba vincero!  102. Simon’s mouth hangs open. Amanda actually begins to cry a the audience rises to it’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vincero. Vincero! The audience are on their feet, roaring... Julz and Yvonn hug each other, bouncing up and down... Even Simon applauds and smiles as the music ends... He looks back at the thundering audience, and actually laugh out loud. Paul takes a deep breath, happy to be finished then just stares at the floor, face tight, expecting the worst.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: So you work at Car Phone Warehouse and you did that. I wasn’t expecting that.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No, neither was I.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: This was a complete breath of fresh air. I thought you were absolutely fantastic. Paul smiles, somewhere between relief and vomiting.

dialogues.speaker: PIERS
dialogues.text: You have an incredible voice. I think, if you keep singing like that, you are going to be one of the favorites to win this competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul nods and smiles shyly at the congratulations from SHOW STAFF and other CONTESTANTS. He heads out the back door just as Julz runs up to embrace him... He hugs her and begins to sob, burying his face in her neck as his entire body is wracked with spasms as the pai of the last three years flows from him in tears of joy.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: It’s all right. It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grimy after-work men watch silently as Paul sings on each of the several televisions. As he begins the final high note, the men erupt into laughter, clapping Roland on the back as tears run down his face. Matthew watches, hating Paul all over again because he’s brave enough to be different. The First Drunk from the beginning leans over to Roland.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRUNK
dialogues.text: Bloody wonderful that. Matthew stands behind Roland, talking with several of the other men.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: What kind of poof sings opera? Roland turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not exactly a chip off the old block, is he?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: A bicycle chain?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Um, well, we were only kids. Roland snarls and levels Matthew with haymaker. Matthew goes down, out cold.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Get this pile’a dung outta my sight. Two men pick up Matthew and carry him to the door, passin Paul, Julz and Yvonne as they enter. A cheer goes up as they’re recognized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Roland stand outside, waiting for their wives.  104.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something... I haven't been the best... Chokes up. Paul puts his hand on his shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dad, you don’t have to--

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Shut up. (deep breath) The only real measure of a father’s success is by how far his children end up surpassing him in life. I’m not good with words...but you should be very, very proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Orgoglio.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s standing back stage in a new tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Always. Think I should open with a joke?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ PAUL
dialogues.text: Probably not. Yeah, probably not.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: If this ended tonight, I’d still love you forever.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: D’you wanna make a run for it?

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: Up to you.  105.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Best not. See what happens. Julz kisses him and puts something in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JULZ
dialogues.text: For luck. Paul looks down to see the 50p coin and the face of Queen Elizabeth II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting beside the DUKE OF EDINBURGH in the royal box as Simon, Amanda and Piers are on-stage.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Now, of course, that was Paul Potts who went on to become the deserving winner of the whole competition. Since then, his first album has already sold over two million copies and he’s been number one in fifteen different countries. Ladies and gentlemen, I’m very proud to introduce Paul Potts.

dialogues.speaker: EMPIRE THEATER, LIVERPOOL, DECEMBER 3, 2007
dialogues.text: A flute plays as an enormous video screen shows images of Paul’s audition and subsequent victory in the finals of Britain’s Got Talent. The screen rises and Paul walks out on stage alongside an entire orchestra and begins to sing... Paul’s nervousness gradually subsides and he looks out at the crowd, seeing the Queen and, several rows behind her, Braddon standing with a very pretty GOTH WOMAN. Braddon smiles and makes a ferret face, nodding over at the woman Paul smiles and continues the song as the CAMERA ORBITS around him, revealing him singing: At the Sydney Opera House...  106.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: PAUL'S DEBUT ALBUM “ONE CHANCE” OPENED AT NUMBER ONE, OUTSELLING THE REST OF THE TOP-TEN COMBINED. On the Oprah Winfrey Show...

dialogues.speaker: HIS SOLD-OUT TOURS HAVE CIRCLED THE GLOBE FIVE TIMES
dialogues.text: Before 70,000 fans in Germany...

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO OF THE REAL PAUL AND JULIE-ANN POTTS
dialogues.text: SHIRTS SAYING “BRAD” AND “CAMERON” RESPECTIVELY.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE FAMOUS VIDEO OF PAUL’S ACTUAL AUDITION FOR BRITAIN’S GOT TALENT PLAYING ALONGSIDE THE END CREDITS...
